","person":{"name":"Visnu Pitiyanuvath","twitter":"visnup","pronouns":"he/him"}}},{"8:15 PM":{"title":"Intermission","emoji":"🕣"}},{"8:30 PM":{"emoji":"🎸","type":"Performance","title":"Ukulele Performance","description":"Visnu and Yuqing will sing a duet!

Just across the street."}}],"charity":{"Black Girls Code":"http://www.blackgirlscode.com/"},"sponsors":[{"Hover":"https://hover.to/jobs/"},{"Retool":"https://tryretool.com/jobs"},{"Intercom":"https://www.intercom.com/careers"}]},{"day":"2020-02-05","schedule":[{"7:00 PM":{"title":"Get some tasty doughnuts and make new friends!","emoji":"🍩"}},{"7:30 PM":{"title":"Introductions","emoji":"👋"}},{"7:45 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"🛡️","title":"How a Statute Helped Shape the Internet, for Both Good and Bad","description":"Section 230 was a part of the Communications Decency Act of 1996. While the act
itself was meant to restrict free speech, Section 230 has allowed internet companies to
operate as distributors of information, like bookstores, instead of traditional publishers,
such as newspapers. The consequences of this freedom has been both
good and bad. I'm going to talk about the challenges of keeping people safe while
companies have started to moderate abuse, hate speech, and disinformation.

Content Warning: High-level discussion of pornography. Brief mentions of violations of consent,
terrorism, discrimination, vaccine misinformation, Trump, white supremacy.
","person":{"name":"Erica Kwan","twitter":"pui_ling","pronouns":"she/her"}}},{"8:00 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"🔰","title":"Math, I cannot stress this enough, keeps changing","description":"Let’s take a journey to the depths of JavaScript to see how trigonometry
is hard even for computers, and how a detail of the language specification
means that you can’t be sure about, well… anything.
","person":{"name":"Tom MacWright","twitter":"tmcw","pronouns":"he/him"}}},{"8:15 PM":{"title":"Intermission","emoji":"🕣"}},{"8:30 PM":"Performer TBA"},{"8:45 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"🧩","title":"Woman Yelling at a Crossword: A Story of Redemption","description":"Whenever I tell people I'm into crosswords, they compulsively and emphatically say that they're NOT good at crosswords. They're just not one of those people! They don't know enough trivia! They tried once and it didn't work! But I'm here to report, from the other side of a Saturday, that it's all just debugging.
","person":{"name":"Heather Rivers","twitter":"heatherrivers","pronouns":"she/her"}}},{"9:00 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"🐹","title":"ESM - JavaScript's Quiet Revolution","description":"There's a quiet revolution going on in JavaScript. Have you noticed? ESM -- the official ES Module syntax -- has finally shipped in Node.js and reached feasibility for websites and applications to ship directly to browsers. This talk will explain why this may be the most radical change to happen to JavaScript since Node.js.
","person":{"name":"Fred Schott","twitter":"FredKSchott","pronouns":"he/him"}}},{"9:15 PM":{"title":"Open karaoke + bevera.js","emoji":"🎤","description":"Head over to [Butter](https://goo.gl/maps/1g8GPrFvJyS2) for karaoke and beverages. Cash bar and open karaoke! Just across the street."}}],"charity":{"Black Girls Code":"http://www.blackgirlscode.com/"},"sponsors":[{"Retool":"https://tryretool.com/jobs"},{"Braid Health":"https://braid.health/"},{"Hover":"https://hover.to/jobs/"},{"Intercom":"https://www.intercom.com/careers"}]},{"day":"2020-01-08","schedule":[{"7:00 PM":{"title":"Get some tasty doughnuts and make new friends!","emoji":"🍩"}},{"7:30 PM":{"title":"Introductions","emoji":"👋"}},{"7:45 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"📈","title":"Modified Star Schemas: Structuring Your Data to Combat Dashboard Entropy","description":"Big Data == Slow Data?
The transfortmational layer standing between your data warehouse and your amazing visualization
often doesn't receive the thoughtful design it deserves.
I'm going to talk about crafting a standardized data transformation layer as a building block for readable, 
modular, and delightfully speedy metrics and data viz.
","person":{"name":"Kristen Werner","twitter":"orbitist","pronouns":"she/her"}}},{"8:00 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"🦖","title":"Why I switched to Fossil SCM for my side projects","description":"Fossil is a simple, high-reliability, distributed software configuration management system (as stated on their website) so it’s like Git but it has some cool features that I find especially powerful for my myriad side projects. I’ll talk about why I think it's cool, how I've set it up, and what the downsides are.
","person":{"name":"Mark Williams","twitter":"mdfw","pronouns":"he/him"}}},{"8:15 PM":{"title":"Intermission","emoji":"🕣"}},{"8:30 PM":{"type":"Performance","emoji":"😆","title":"Laughter meditation","description":"Frazer's famous laughter sessions have been dubbed as the best laughter sessions in the world.
They are incredibly hysterical and liberating. We start with happiness warm ups and some positive
thoughts and smiles, we move on to big laughs and ecstatic ecstaticness, finishing with a
relaxation and contemplation. He has intentionally created this practice to explore feeling
fantastic, and also for us to contemplate and cultivate positive states of mind.
The outcome is to brain program these in the other areas of our life.
","person":{"name":"Frazer Kirkman","twitter":"FrazerKirkman","pronouns":"it/he/him"}}},{"8:45 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"🔄","title":"Feedback loops","description":"Feedback loops are an effective way to make any kind of work more meaningful, impactful, and
fun. Good feedback loops encourage states of flow, in which we’re completely engrossed in the
thing we’re doing, engaging way more of our brainpower and providing a sense of joy. In this
talk, I’ll discuss how to build and sustain good feedback loops for software development!
","person":{"name":"Max Edmands","twitter":"thismax","pronouns":"she/her"}}},{"9:00 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"🖋️","title":"Variable Fonts","description":"Variable fonts allow designers and developers to dynamically change various parameters 
of a typeface, going beyond commonly adjusted attributes like font-size and font-weight 
to attributes like y-ascender height and optical size. This can be a powerful tool 
and also lead to some fun use cases.
","person":{"name":"Jay Mahabal","twitter":"jaymahabal","pronouns":"he/him"}}},{"9:15 PM":{"title":"Open karaoke + bevera.js","emoji":"🎤","description":"Head over to [Butter](https://goo.gl/maps/1g8GPrFvJyS2) for karaoke and beverages. Cash bar and open karaoke! Just across the street."}}],"charity":{"Black Girls Code":"http://www.blackgirlscode.com/"},"sponsors":[{"Retool":"https://tryretool.com/jobs"},{"Opendoor":"https://www.opendoor.com/jobs"},{"Intercom":"https://www.intercom.com/careers"}]},{"day":"2019-12-04","schedule":[{"7:00 PM":{"title":"Get some tasty doughnuts and make new friends!","emoji":"🍩"}},{"7:30 PM":{"title":"Introductions","emoji":"👋"}},{"7:45 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"🌱","title":"How to Develop as a Leader: Ask for that Big, Hairy Project. Then Go Make Mistakes.","description":"There are some clear stepping stones when you want to grow as an engineer. But what about when you want to grow as a leader? Or develop more cross-functional skills, like influencing decisions across an organization or proposing more strategic engineering initiatives?
Well, you take on that messy, large, and challenging project!
Together, we'll explore how you can seek out career-changing projects, strategies to tackle them, and the benefits of embarking on what could be a true growth period in your career.
","person":{"name":"Tripta Gupta","github":"neurosaurus","pronouns":"she"}}},{"8:00 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"🤖","title":"How to showcase your creative side using robots","description":"Most of the robots in our lives live life behind the scenes- helping us vacuum, serving us coffee, etc. But what if there was a way to create more robot entertainment and fun in the world? Sound cool but have no idea where to start? In this presentation Chris will show you how "welcome our robot overlords" with fun, creative, and and unique use cases.
","person":{"name":"Chris Meyer","twitter":"admirethemeyer","pronouns":"he/him"}}},{"8:15 PM":{"title":"Intermission","emoji":"🕣"}},{"8:30 PM":{"type":"Performance","emoji":"💃","title":"Robot Perfomance Art","description":"Chloe and Misty present a mini-variety *hour of entertainment. (*in way less than an hour)
","person":{"name":"Chloe Condon","twitter":"ChloeCondon","pronouns":"she/her"}}},{"8:45 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"🌐","title":"First steps toward Universal JavaScript","description":"Universal JavaScript, JS that works in Browser and in Node.js without a compiler, are possible but currently very difficult. Many features we’ve come to rely on, like npm and Node’s dynamic module system, are not available. In this talk Mikeal will talk about some of these problems, particularly in package management, and show a new project that embraces the constraints native ESM imposes to create a new and even improved experience over our existing toolchains.
","person":{"name":"Mikeal Rogers","twitter":"mikeal","pronouns":"he/him"}}},{"9:00 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"🎅","title":"The Night Before Code Freeze","description":"'Twas the night before Code Freeze, when all thro'out git,

There are many ways to execute JavaScript and this talk will go into details on how to perform Blind XSS against legacy and modern applications.","person":{"name":"Lewis Ardern","twitter":"LewisArdern","pronouns":"he/him"}}},{"8:00 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"🌎","title":"Civic Hacking (in your free time)","description":"Does life right now make you yearn for passion projects with a civic focus? Unsure of where to find repos that you can contribute to part time so you don’t burn out? Does the thought of having your code publicly reviewed make your stomach twist into geometric shapes? This talk addresses all of these topics in < 10 minutes!
","person":{"name":"Sarah Yu","github":"SYU15","pronouns":"she/her"}}},{"8:15 PM":{"title":"Intermission","emoji":"🕣"}},{"8:30 PM":"Performer TBA"},{"8:45 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"🔬","title":"Have fun with Node.js loader hooks!","description":"The latests versions of Node.js introduce a hook system to intercept all loaded modules. All of that can be done!
","person":{"name":"Vladimir de Turckheim","twitter":"poledesfetes","pronouns":"he/him"}}},{"9:00 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"🎱","title":"How to hustle your codebase","description":"Approaching code re-architectures through the eyes of a billiards player.

","person":{"name":"Ker Lee Yap","twitter":"_klyap_","pronouns":"she/her"}}},{"8:15 PM":{"title":"Intermission","emoji":"🕣"}},{"8:30 PM":{"type":"Performance","emoji":"🦇","title":"Addams Family Theme Song","description":"A sing-along with Andy on the Tuba!","person":{"name":"Andy Tuba","twitter":"andytuba","pronouns":"he/him"}}},{"8:45 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"🌱","title":"Growing Javascript","description":"Every year, new features are added to JavaScript. It's exciting, but as curious software engineers, we should ask ourselves: how is JavaScript as a language growing, and to what end? In this talk, I'll introduce the idea of architecting a programming language that isn’t created all at once, but rather one that grows over time, drawing analogies from urbanism and linguistics.
","person":{"name":"Sravanti Tekumalla","twitter":"sravanti__","pronouns":"she/her/hers"}}},{"9:00 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"🏔️","title":"Designing very large (JavaScript) applications","description":"I used to build very large JavaScript applications. I don’t really do that anymore, so I thought it was a good time to give a bit of a retrospective and share what I learned.
","person":{"name":"Malte Ubl","twitter":"cramforce","pronouns":"he/him"}}},{"9:15 PM":{"title":"Open karaoke + bevera.js","emoji":"🎤","description":"Head over to [Butter](https://goo.gl/maps/1g8GPrFvJyS2) for karaoke and beverages. Melody will share current data and tips to evaluate your own productivity.
","person":{"name":"Melody Meckfessel","twitter":"mmeckf","pronouns":"she/her"}}},{"8:15 PM":{"title":"Intermission","emoji":"🕣"}},{"8:30 PM":{"type":"Performance","emoji":"😆","title":"Laughter meditation","description":"Frazer's famous laughter sessions have been dubbed as the best laughter sessions in the world.
They are incredibly hysterical and liberating. We start with happiness warm ups and some positive
thoughts and smiles, we move on to big laughs and ecstatic ecstaticness, finishing with a
relaxation and contemplation. He has intentionally created this practice to explore feeling
fantastic, and also for us to contemplate and cultivate positive states of mind.
The outcome is to brain program these in the other areas of our life.
","person":{"name":"Frazer Kirkman","twitter":"FrazerKirkman","pronouns":"it/he/him"}}},{"8:45 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"🌈","title":"Introduction to Optimism","description":"Webapps we build should be not just RESTful, but RESPECTful... of our users' time.
In this talk-slash-food-fight, we'll look at one technique for writing performant frontends
(optimistic rendering) and weigh its pros and cons.
","person":{"name":"Logan Davis","twitter":"logankeahidavis","pronouns":"he/him"}}},{"9:00 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"👋","title":"WaffleJS: A Retrospective
","description":"Billy is leaving WaffleJS! Come listen to a short story about WaffleJS started and how we
got here.

Cash bar and open karaoke! Just across the street."}}],"charity":{"Black Girls Code":"http://www.blackgirlscode.com/"},"sponsors":[{"Medium":"https://medium.com/jobs-at-medium/"},{"Storj":"https://storj.io/careers/"},{"Twilio":"https://www.twilio.com/company/jobs"}]},{"day":"2019-08-07","schedule":[{"7:00 PM":{"title":"Get some tasty doughnuts and make new friends!","emoji":"🍩"}},{"7:30 PM":{"title":"Introductions","emoji":"👋"}},{"7:45 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"✨","title":"Juice Box Driven Design","description":"A talk about building for mental health: why lightweight apps are so important 
and how to engage people without bogging down your product.
","person":{"name":"Evan Conrad","twitter":"flaqueEau","pronouns":"he/him"}}},{"8:00 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"😴","title":"Boredom is good actually","description":"I took a few months off of work and I'm going to tell you what I learned
on my summer vacation. Spoiler alert: boredom is good.
","person":{"name":"Duretti Hirpa","twitter":"duretti","pronouns":"she/her"}}},{"8:15 PM":{"title":"Intermission","emoji":"🕣"}},{"8:30 PM":{"type":"Performance","emoji":"🎤","title":"Live karaoke","description":"A rockin' live karaoke performance!

","description":"What can you do today to reinforce your dedication to support the marginalized? I’ll be sharing 10 tiny microallyship patches we can apply to our environment to support our folks, starting right now!
","person":{"name":"Neha Batra","twitter":"nerdneha","pronouns":"she/her"}}},{"9:00 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"🔌","title":"Benefits of a plugin-based framework","description":"Identifying some of the benefits of using a plugin-based framework for developing React applications in a large organisation.
","person":{"name":"Carsten Jacobsen","twitter":"carstenjacobsen","pronouns":"he/him"}}},{"9:15 PM":{"title":"Open karaoke + bevera.js","emoji":"🎤","description":"Head over to [Butter](https://goo.gl/maps/1g8GPrFvJyS2) for karaoke and beverages. Just across the street."}}],"charity":{"Black Girls Code":"http://www.blackgirlscode.com/"},"sponsors":[{"GitHub":"https://github.com/about/careers/"},{"Medium":"https://medium.com/jobs-at-medium/"},{"Airtable":"https://airtable.com/jobs"}]},{"day":"2019-07-03","mc":{"emoji":"✨🔥","name":"Thais Correia","twitter":"isthisthais","pronouns":"they/them/she/her"},"schedule":[{"7:00 PM":{"title":"Get some tasty doughnuts and make new friends!","emoji":"🍩"}},{"7:30 PM":{"title":"Introductions","emoji":"👋"}},{"7:45 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"🎵","title":"Tail Call Optimization: the Musical","description":"“Stack overflow”! “Maximum call stack size exceeded”!! “Too much recursion”!!!<br><br>
You may have seen errors like these when you attempt to run a deeply recursive function. Computers can be so dramatic! But what’s the conflict, exactly, between recursion and call stacks? And is there any hope for resolving it into a happy ending? In this musical talk we'll see why recursion poses a problem for our finite-memory call stack, and learn how "Tail Call Optimization" (TCO) lets us get around that problem.<br><br>
We’ll sing our way through the meaning of these terms to explore how TCO messes with the call stack (in a useful way!), as we mess with the lyrics to some of our favorite animated musical songs (in a nerdy way!).
","people":[{"name":"Natalia Margolis","twitter":"nsmargolis","pronouns":"she/her"},{"name":"Anjana Vakil","twitter":"AnjanaVakil","pronouns":"she/her"}]}},{"8:00 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"🥃","title":"Keeping 100% Lighthouse score around the world","description":"Performance is crucial to designing a delightful user experience. Yet even products with a 100% Lighthouse score often fall short in some regions of the world. You can determine your performance worldwide by measuring field data with Real User Monitoring (RUM) via Perfume.js. In this talk we’ll study how we use Perfume.js at Coinbase to maximize our performance around the globe.

has [NIST Special Publication 800-53](http://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/SpecialPublications/NIST.SP.800-53r4.pdf), a

inspiring.

","description":"If you were to try and make a webVR website from scratch right now I'm sure you could do it, but
there’d be a lot of boiler plate: handling VR events like screen connection,
handling head rotation & a myriad of controllers, performantly writing webGL to render the scene - and what
about mobile and desktop users?! Well, there’s this Javascript framework [A-Frame](https://aframe.io/) that
makes it easy to quickly make VR scenes using HTML web component-like syntax. It’s also designed
to be easy to extend with your own components written in Javascript. I’ll be going through what
A-Frame gives you, how to get started, and some examples of what you can do with the library!
","person":{"name":"Andrés Cuervo","twitter":"acwervo","pronouns":"they/them or he/him"}}},{"8:15 PM":{"title":"Intermission","emoji":"🕣"}},{"8:30 PM":{"type":"Performance","emoji":"🎤🎸","title":"Soel","description":"A vocal and guitar duo.","people":[{"name":"Sahana Rajasekar","twitter":"sahanarajasekar","pronouns":"she/her"},{"name":"Noel Moldvai","twitter":"noeleo91","pronouns":"he/him"}]}},{"8:45 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"🎉","title":"Practical Things You Can Do to Protect the Privacy of Your Users
","description":"Protecting privacy is the right thing to do. Consider especially that
a few of your users may be people such as political dissidents or
victims of domestic abuse that are especially vulnerable to privacy
violation. Protecting privacy also makes business sense. You want to
protect against a big data breach that could destroy your company's
reputation, or to comply with upcoming European privacy regulations
that apply to all apps worldwide. However privacy can be hard to get a
handle on, because it is often explained using legal jargon. In this
talk I speak as a fellow developer and outline the practical
engineering things you can do, concentrating on protecting data you
store in your backends.
","person":{"name":"Eamonn O'Brien-Strain","twitter":"eob","pronouns":"he/him"}}},{"9:00 PM":{"type":"Talk","emoji":"💚","title":"So Fast You'll Think It Broke: Content-Addressable Disk Caching in Pure JS","description":"[cacache](https://npm.im/cacache) is a content-addressable cache that was written as

disk access patterns that npm needed. This talk will teach you about content-addressable caching,
what it is, when to use it, and include various lessons learned while trying to optimize
parallel disk access while guaranteeing data integrity. Expect general tips-and-tricks for
efficient (and safe!) general I/O when using Node.js!
","person":{"name":"Kat Marchán","twitter":"maybekatz","pronouns":"they/them (or she/her)"}}},{"9:15 PM":{"title":"Open karaoke + bevera.js","emoji":"🎤","description":"Head over to [Butter](https://goo.gl/maps/1g8GPrFvJyS2) for karaoke and beverages. ","description":""Works for me." The words spoken to dismiss a thousand bugs. "Can't Reproduce." Issue closed. "You're getting worked up over nothing." "It was just a joke." "I worked just as hard to get here." "It didn't bother me." Problem dismissed. "Works for me" is a natural reaction when confronted with cultural issues that don't impact us directly. It's a statement that isn't inaccurate, but is wildly incomplete. We have to learn to see past our own experiences and see and accept the experiences of others. This talk will dive into how and why dismissal of culture concerns happens in the tech community, and how we can combat it with knowledge and empathy.

But there's one number that's super magical, and almost all of us have interacted with it as JavaScript developers. The number 16! This talk will look at the awesomeness of hexadeimcal numbers. We'll explore the logic behind color hex codes, and the math that's behind converting between rgb and hex codes. ","person":{"name":"Brian Bloniarz","github":"b11z"}}},{"8:45 PM":{"type":"Talk","title":"Resilient Web Applications","emoji":"🔏","description":"How do we build web apps that work under poor network conditions?
How do we build web apps that protect our privacy?
Building applications that are resilient to hostile networks and governments is
not a matter swapping out one service for another, it requires that we
rethink many of our assumptions about trust and infrastructure. It requires
that we build a lot more open source software infrastructure to make the
basic tools like signing and encryption as usable as we've made the rest
of our software infrastructure.
","person":{"name":"Mikeal Rogers","twitter":"mikeal"}}},{"9:00 PM":{"type":"Talk","title":"Embracing change as an Open Source product","emoji":"🔄","description":"The Open Source project I work on, BOSH, has been able to adapt to changing
product and engineering needs over the past 3 years. I'll talk about some of
the major changes that we've made while growing our contributor base. We
transitioned from waterfall to XP, scaled our team to be globally distributed,
and replaced core architectural components with zero downtime. While the

","7:30 PM":"**Hello**

EMILY

  Hi! My name is **Emily**.

VISNU

  Hi! My name is **Visnu**. Welcome to WaffleJS and thank you for coming
  tonight. You should’ve met **Billy** and **Kelly** too on your way in. They
  likely checked you in and pointed out the waffles. We’re all organizers, so
  if you need anything feel free to grab us.

  Lots of people here, which I’m sure you’re feeling if you’re stuck
  standing. So please if you’re a lucky seated person, please crowd in and
  get comfy and try to make room for one or two more people to sit next to
  you. And definitely, if you see an **empty seat, please take it** but you
  just have to **say hi to your new neighbor**. Also, if hanging out and
  talking is more your thang, feel free to chill in the area outside so
  people who want to see and hear the talks can do that.


**Talks**

EMILY

  So we have a total of **4x 10ish-minute lightning talks** with
  **{{script.speakers[0].name}}** and **{{script.speakers[1].name}}** going
  first, then a nice little intermission. At the end of intermission,
  **{{script.performers[0][0].name}}** will be performing, followed by
  **{{script.speakers[2].name}}** and finally **{{script.speakers[3].name}}**
  after that.

  We’ve got lots of stuff packed into two hours, so **if you’ve got
  questions** we encourage you to find your favorite speaker **after their
  talk** and ask them all your questions.


**Bevera.js + Karaoke**

VISNU

  If you’re down to hang out afterwards, we’re going to **Butter** for
  karaoke and drinks tonight which is just **1-block north on 11th Street**.
  We call it Bevera.js and Karaoke, with naming credits to **Will Duffy**
  from Brooklyn JS.


**Wed, May 4**

EMILY

  This is the **?th WaffleJS**! We have it the **first Wednesday of every
  month**, always in this nice cozy barn. The next one is **?** and if
